You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 431, 222, 446]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 868, 648]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 676, 213, 691]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 693, 728, 725]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
In a certain country, the heights of the adult population are normally distributed with mean \(1.64 \text{m}\) and standard deviation \(0.25 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 146, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 128, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that an adult chosen at random from this country will have height greater than \(1.93 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
In another country, the heights of the adult population are also normally distributed. \(33\%\) of the adult population have height less than \(1.56 \text{m}\). \(25\%\) of the adult population have height greater than \(1.86 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 129, 146, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 129, 631, 148]]<|/det|>
Find the mean and the standard deviation of this distribution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 129, 920, 148]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 494, 101]]<|/det|>
Box \(A\) contains 6 green balls and 3 yellow balls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 494, 131]]<|/det|>
Box \(B\) contains 4 green balls and \(x\) yellow balls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 144, 910, 163]]<|/det|>
A ball is chosen at random from box \(A\) and placed in box \(B\). A ball is then chosen at random from box \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 175, 146, 194]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 175, 920, 194]]<|/det|>
Draw a tree diagram to represent this information, showing the probability on each of the branches.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 192, 920, 210]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 88, 653, 112]]<|/det|>
The probability that both the balls chosen are the same colour is \(\frac{8}{15}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 122, 146, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 122, 311, 140]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 122, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 81, 92, 100]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 920, 119]]<|/det|> The times taken, in seconds, by 15 members of each of two swimming clubs, the Penguins and the Dolphins, to swim 50 metres are shown in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 129, 922, 188]]<|/det|>
Penguins353942444545485056585961666872
Dolphins364143484949505154565660616471
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 199, 144, 217]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 198, 920, 234]]<|/det|> Draw a back-to-back stem-and-leaf diagram to represent this information, with Penguins on the left-hand side. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 217, 920, 235]]<|/det|> [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 771, 101]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a box-and-whisker plot representing the times for the Penguins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 114, 146, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 114, 868, 133]]<|/det|>
On the same diagram, draw a box-and-whisker plot to represent the times for the Dolphins. [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 144, 794, 388]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 514, 146, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 920, 548]]<|/det|>
Hence state **one** difference between the distributions of the times for the Penguins and the Dolphins. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 92, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
Salah decides to attempt the crossword puzzle in his newspaper each day. The probability that he will complete the puzzle on any given day is 0.65, independent of other days.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 128, 146, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 128, 813, 147]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Salah completes the puzzle for the first time on the 5th day.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 129, 920, 148]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 284, 146, 303]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 284, 836, 303]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Salah completes the puzzle for the second time on the 5th day.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 285, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 560, 186, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 560, 865, 579]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Salah completes the puzzle fewer than 5 times in a week (7 days).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 561, 920, 580]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 148, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 81, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximation to find the probability that Salah completes the puzzle more than 50 times in a period of 84 days.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 82, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
The 9 letters of the word RECORDERS are divided at random into two groups: a group of 5 letters and a group of 4 letters.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 129, 143, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 129, 623, 148]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the three Rs are in the same group.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 129, 920, 148]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
